module.p: feum necessity, need has a number of uses.

Examples of usage –
[...] A nis, tha an Taghadh Nàiseanta seachad, agus tha Riaghaltas ùr againn. Tha sinn an dòchas gun téid gu math dhaibh, agus gun cuir iad spionnadh ás ùr anns an dùthaich air fad. Agus gu seachd àraidh anns a’ Ghaidhealtachd: gun tòisich obair an dealain a rithist, gun cuirear tuilleadh bhàtaichean-iasgaich an sàs, gum faigh na Gaidheil cothrom air fearann na Gaidhealtachd obrachadh dhaibh fhéin, ás bith an ann mar chroitean no mar innis no mar choille, gun bhacadh o bhàllidh no o thighearna. Tha sinn an dòchas gun tig rathaidean ùra, chan ann dìreach gu feum an luchd-turais, ach gu feum nan Gaidheal.
[...] Now, the General Election is behind [us], and we have a new Government. We hope that they will do well, and that they will re-energise the whole country. And most especially in the Highlands: that electricity work will restart, that more fishing boats will be put into service [?], that the Gaels will get the opportunity to work the land of the Highlands for themselves, whether as crofts or as grazing or as forest, without hindrance from a bailiff or from a laird. We hope that new roads will come, not just to benefit tourists, but to benefit the Gaels. td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Bhiodh a leòr aige ri dhèanamh an toiseach ag ath-nuadhachadh dreach a’ Chomuinn. [...] Ach dh’ fheumadh am Fear-stiùiridh ùr barrachd air a sin a dhèanamh. Dh’ fheumadh e siubhal a dhèanamh eadar Rubha Robhanais agus Ceann Bharraidh, eadar am Parbh is Maol Chinn-tìre, agus cha deanadh math dha dìochuimhneachadh gu robh obair a’ Chomuinn a’ buntainn ri Coimisean nan Croitearan an Inbhirnis, ri Roinn an Fhoghluim an Dùn-Eideann, agus ri Tigh nan Cumantan an Lunnainn. An duine a theid do gach àite dhiubh sin, agus a bheir barrachd air còmhradh leis dhachaidh, nì e feum do ’n Chomunn is do ’n Ghàidhlig.
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] He would have enough to do initially reforming the Society. [...] But the new leader would have to do more than (just) that. He would have to travel between the Butt of Lewis and Barra Head, between Cape Wrath and the Mull of Kintyre, and he should not forget that the Society’s work is related to the Crofters’ Commission in Inverness, to the Education Department in Edinburgh, and to the House of Commons in London. The person who goes to each of those places, and who brings home more than (just) conversation, will benefit the Society and the Gaelic language. td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’
Bha beagan airgid aige ’s mar sin chaith e a bheatha a’ sgrìobhadh, gun feum aige air obair eile a dhèanamh.
He had a little money and therefore he devoted his life to writing, without the need to do other work. td. 103

Examples from Gairm –
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Cha b’ fhuilear do dhuine de ’n t-seòrsa so tomhas mhath de chumhachd a bhith aige. Cha dean math dha a bhith air a shlaodadh aig tòin Coimitidh, ach feumaidh an Coimitidh earbsa a bhith aca ás. [...] Bhiodh a leòr aige ri dhèanamh an toiseach ag ath-nuadhachadh dreach a’ Chomuinn. [...] Ach dh’ fheumadh am Fear-stiùiridh ùr barrachd air a sin a dhèanamh. Dh’ fheumadh e siubhal a dhèanamh eadar Rubha Robhanais agus Ceann Bharraidh, eadar am Parbh is Maol Chinn-tìre, agus cha deanadh math dha dìochuimhneachadh gu robh obair a’ Chomuinn a’ buntainn ri Coimisean nan Croitearan an Inbhirnis, ri Roinn an Fhoghluim an Dùn-Eideann, agus ri Tigh nan Cumantan an Lunnainn.
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] A person of this kind would have to have a good measure of power. It would do him no good to be dragged along by the Committee ??, but the Committee must have trust in him. [...] He would have enough to do initially reforming the Society. [...] But the new leader would have to do more than (just) that. He would have to travel between the Butt of Lewis and Barra Head, between Cape Wrath and the Mull of Kintyre, and he should not forget that the Society’s work is related to the Crofters’ Commission in Inverness, to the Education Department in Edinburgh, and to the House of Commons in London. td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’
’Se madainn bhòidheach foghair a bh’ ann—tioram, le ceileir eòin, is beagan dealt air an fheur. Bha a[m] muir ’s na tighean ag éirigh á inntinn an latha. Cha robh e fhéin a’ faireachdainn uabhasach math, oir, air a’ bhàta, bha triùir dhaoine le botul uisge-bheatha agus cha robh càil air a shon ach gu feumadh e òl ’nan cuideachd.
It was a beautiful autumn morning – dry, with the chirping of birds, and a little dew on the grass. The sea and the houses were rising from the mind of the day [?]. He was not feeling terribly good/well, because, on the boat, there were three men with a bottle of whisky and there was nothing for it but that he would have to drink in their company. td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. [...] Bha seachdnar de theaghlach aige, ceathrar mhac agus triùir nighean, agus bha a h-uile fear is tè anns a’ mhalairt ach Rob. B’ e Rob a b’ òige agus lean e an sgoil. Nuair a ràinig e an t-oilthigh bha càch airson gun ionnsaicheadh e cunntasachd, a bhiodh feumail anns a’ mhalairt, ach ’s ann a bha ùidh-san ann an ealain. Dh’fhàg e an t-oilthigh agus chaidh e do sgoil ealain. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. [...] He had a family of seven, four sons and three daughters, and every man and woman was in the business except Rob. Rob was the youngest and he stayed on at school. When he reached the university the others wanted him to learn accountancy, which would be useful in the business, but his interest was in art. He left the university and went to an art school. [...] td. 5
